para.paratext: The jury should consider all opinion testimony.[1] If the subject is one solely within the knowledge of experts, the jury cannot disregard uncontradicted expert testimony.[2]

Expert opinion, no matter how strong, is never enough for a summary judgment.[3] However, in Howard v. Walker,[4] the Georgia Supreme Court held that in cases when the defendant produces an expert's opinion in his favor on motion for summary judgment and the plaintiff fails to oppose with a contrary expert opinion, then the defendant is entitled to summary judgment. The Howard ruling has been applied in other cases[5] in which the plaintiff is required to present expert testimony. It did not apply in a negligence suit against a hospital.[6]

In Cogland v. Hospital Authority of City of Bainbridge,[7] a patient's expert affidavit submitted in her medical malpractice action against hospital authority and physical therapist failed to show that the physician expert was qualified by recent or continuing experience in orthopedics.

In McGuire Holdings, LLLP v. TSQ Partners, LLC,[8] the trial court properly struck a surveyor's summary judgment affidavit in which he averred that a dominant estate had been graded to an average elevation under 1,064 feet, in an easement action that required the owner of the servient estate to grade the dominant estate to an average elevation of 1,067 feet, because surveyor offered no testimony regarding his qualifications or experience, and did not identify the principles and methods he employed in reaching his conclusions.

In Savannah Valley Production Credit Ass'n v. Cheek,[9] the Georgia Supreme Court answered certified questions in regard to Howard v. Walker as follows: (1) the rule of Howard v. Walker is not limited to malpractice cases, but applies in all cases where a contention of fact is capable of proof only by expert testimony, (2) it does not apply in all situations where expert testimony is used in summary judgment cases, only those in (1), above, (3) the rule of Ginn v. Morgan and its progeny has been modified only to the extent discussed in (1), above, (4) in a summary judgment proceeding where expert opinion is presented to prove an issue that may be established by expert or non-expert opinion, the opposing party will be required to present expert opinion only in those cases set out in (1), above.
The following jury charge regarding expert opinion testimony based upon mistakes of fact or incorrect assumptions was approved by the Georgia Court of Appeals in Flint v. Department of Transp.:[10]

[A]n opinion of an expert witness which is shown to your satisfaction to be based on a mistake of facts or mistakes of fact should not be considered by you and should be dismissed from your deliberations since it rests upon an improper basis, if that is shown. I further instruct you that certain witnesses in this case have testified based on certain assumptions which they have made …. I charge you that if you find that these assumptions … are not correct or are unreasonable, then I instruct you that you should disregard the conclusion of that witness as to that issue which you find to be based on such erroneous [assumptions as to facts].[11]
The court stated this was a proper charge because it simply “allowed the jury to disregard the expert's conclusions to the extent they were based upon a mistake of fact.”[12]
Cates v. Harris, 217 Ga. 801, 125 S.E.2d 649 (1962); Ford Motor Co. v. Hanley, 128 Ga. App. 311, 196 S.E.2d 454 (1973); Longshore v. State, 242 Ga. 689, 251 S.E.2d 280 (1978).
Truelove v. Hulette, 103 Ga. App. 641, 120 S.E.2d 342 (1961); Martin v. Newton, 129 Ga. App. 735, 201 S.E.2d 31 (1973).
Ginn v. Morgan, 225 Ga. 192, 167 S.E.2d 393 (1969); Truluck v. Funderburk, 119 Ga. App. 734, 168 S.E.2d 657 (1969); Williams v. Melton, 120 Ga. App. 466, 171 S.E.2d 318 (1969).

Ginn was applied in Scott v. Owens-Illinois, Inc., 173 Ga. App. 19, 325 S.E.2d 402 (1984), in a negligence case. The court stated that opinion evidence alone can never sustain an award of a summary judgment, but that opinion evidence by the non-moving party might be sufficient to preclude an award of summary judgment.

However, in Dickson v. Dickson, 238 Ga. 672, 235 S.E.2d 479 (1977), the court held that opinion evidence by affidavit might be sufficient to preclude the grant of summary judgment. In that case, the court disapproved the case of Manning v. Manning, 237 Ga. 746, 229 S.E.2d 611 (1976).
Howard v. Walker, 242 Ga. 406, 249 S.E.2d 45 (1978). See Walker v. Howard, 149 Ga. App. 41, 253 S.E.2d 434 (1979).

E.g., Watson v. Worthy, 151 Ga. App. 131, 259 S.E.2d 138 (1979); Phillips v. Cheek, 162 Ga. App. 728, 293 S.E.2d 22 (1982) (chiropractic malpractice); Dobbs v. Cobb E.N.T. Associates, P.C., 165 Ga. App. 238, 299 S.E.2d 141 (1983).

However, the material presented by the defendant must be sufficient to authorize the grant of summary judgment. See Lawrence v. Gardner, 154 Ga. App. 722, 270 S.E.2d 9 (1980); Skinner v. Coleman-Nincic Urology Clinic, P.A., 156 Ga. App. 638, 275 S.E.2d 724 (1980).

In Larson v. Friedman & Snyder, 154 Ga. App. 702, 269 S.E.2d 532 (1980), the court pointed out that if a plaintiff in a malpractice action has been unable to obtain expert opinion, he should file an affidavit to this effect under O.C.G.A. § 9-11-56(f) and the court may order a continuance.

In Gilbert v. R.J. Taylor Memorial Hosp., Inc., 265 Ga. 580, 458 S.E.2d 341 (1995), the Georgia Supreme Court held that plaintiff's expert testimony that no doctor could reach the conclusions that were reached by the defendant's experts was sufficient to overcome the defendant's motion for summary judgment.
